text: After the death of Joshua, the Israelites inquired of the Lord, “Who shall go up first for us against the Canaanites, to fight against them?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said, “Judah shall go up. I hereby give the land into his hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah said to his brother Simeon, “Come up with me into the territory allotted to me, that we may fight against the Canaanites; then I, too, will go with you into the territory allotted to you.” So Simeon went with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Judah went up, and the Lord gave the Canaanites and the Perizzites into their hand, and they defeated ten thousand of them at Bezek.
speaker: Narrator

text: They came upon Adoni-bezek at Bezek and fought against him and defeated the Canaanites and the Perizzites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adoni-bezek fled, but they pursued him and caught him and cut off his thumbs and big toes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adoni-bezek said, “Seventy kings with their thumbs and big toes cut off used to pick up scraps under my table; as I have done, so God has paid me back.” They brought him to Jerusalem, and he died there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the people of Judah fought against Jerusalem and took it. They put it to the sword and set the city on fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward the people of Judah went down to fight against the Canaanites who lived in the hill country, in the Negeb, and in the lowland.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah went against the Canaanites who lived in Hebron (the name of Hebron was formerly Kiriath-arba), and they defeated Sheshai and Ahiman and Talmai.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there they went against the inhabitants of Debir (the name of Debir was formerly Kiriath-sepher).
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Caleb said, “Whoever attacks Kiriath-sepher and takes it, I will give him my daughter Achsah as wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Othniel son of Kenaz, Caleb’s younger brother, took it, and he gave him his daughter Achsah as wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she came to him, she urged him to ask her father for a field. As she dismounted from her donkey, Caleb said to her, “What do you wish?”
speaker: Narrator

text: She said to him, “Give me a blessing; since you have set me in the land of the Negeb, give me also Gulloth-mayim.” So Caleb gave her Upper Gulloth and Lower Gulloth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Hobab the Kenite, Moses’s father-in-law, went up with the people of Judah from the city of palms into the wilderness of Judah, which lies in the Negeb near Arad. Then they went and settled with the Amalekites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah went with his brother Simeon, and they defeated the Canaanites who inhabited Zephath and devoted it to destruction. So the city was called Hormah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah took Gaza with its territory, Ashkelon with its territory, and Ekron with its territory.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord was with Judah, and he took possession of the hill country but could not drive out the inhabitants of the plain, because they had chariots of iron.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hebron was given to Caleb, as Moses had said, and he drove out from it the three sons of Anak.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Benjaminites did not drive out the Jebusites who lived in Jerusalem; so the Jebusites have lived in Jerusalem among the Benjaminites to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The house of Joseph also went up against Bethel, and the Lord was with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The house of Joseph sent out spies to Bethel (the name of the city was formerly Luz).
speaker: Narrator

text: When the spies saw a man coming out of the city, they said to him, “Show us the way into the city, and we will deal kindly with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he showed them the way into the city, and they put the city to the sword, but they let the man and all his family go.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the man went to the land of the Hittites and built a city and named it Luz; that is its name to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Manasseh did not drive out the inhabitants of Beth-shean and its villages, or Taanach and its villages, or the inhabitants of Dor and its villages, or the inhabitants of Ibleam and its villages, or the inhabitants of Megiddo and its villages, but the Canaanites continued to live in that land.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Israel grew strong, they put the Canaanites to forced labor but did not in fact drive them out.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Ephraim did not drive out the Canaanites who lived in Gezer, but the Canaanites lived among them in Gezer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zebulun did not drive out the inhabitants of Kitron or the inhabitants of Nahalol, but the Canaanites lived among them and became subject to forced labor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Asher did not drive out the inhabitants of Acco or the inhabitants of Sidon, or of Mahalab, or of Achzib, or of Helbah, or of Aphik, or of Rehob,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the Asherites lived among the Canaanites, the inhabitants of the land, for they did not drive them out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Naphtali did not drive out the inhabitants of Beth-shemesh or the inhabitants of Beth-anath but lived among the Canaanites, the inhabitants of the land; nevertheless, the inhabitants of Beth-shemesh and of Beth-anath became subject to forced labor for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Amorites pressed the Danites back into the hill country; they did not allow them to come down to the plain.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Amorites continued to live in Har-heres, in Aijalon, and in Shaalbim, but the hand of the house of Joseph rested heavily on them, and they became subject to forced labor.
speaker: Narrator

text: The border of the Amorites ran from the ascent of Akrabbim, from Sela and upward.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the angel of the Lord went up from Gilgal to Bochim and said, “I brought you up from Egypt and brought you into the land that I had promised to your ancestors. I said, ‘I will never break my covenant with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: For your part, do not make a covenant with the inhabitants of this land; tear down their altars.’ But you have not obeyed my command. See what you have done!
speaker: Narrator

text: So now I say, I will not drive them out before you, but they shall become adversaries to you, and their gods shall be a snare to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the angel of the Lord spoke these words to all the Israelites, the people lifted up their voices and wept.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they named that place Bochim, and there they sacrificed to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joshua dismissed the people, the Israelites all went to their own inheritances to take possession of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people served the Lord all the days of Joshua and all the days of the elders who outlived Joshua, who had seen all the great work that the Lord had done for Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua son of Nun, the servant of the Lord, died at the age of one hundred ten years.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they buried him within the bounds of his inheritance in Timnath-heres, in the hill country of Ephraim, north of Mount Gaash.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, that whole generation was gathered to their ancestors, and another generation grew up after them who did not know the Lord or the work that he had done for Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Israelites did what was evil in the sight of the Lord and served the Baals,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they abandoned the Lord, the God of their ancestors, who had brought them out of the land of Egypt; they followed other gods, from among the gods of the peoples who were all around them and bowed down to them, and they provoked the Lord to anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: They abandoned the Lord and served Baal and the Astartes.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the anger of the Lord was kindled against Israel, and he gave them over to plunderers who plundered them, and he sold them into the power of their enemies all around, so that they could no longer withstand their enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever they marched out, the hand of the Lord was against them to bring misfortune, as the Lord had warned them and sworn to them, and they were in great distress.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord raised up judges who delivered them out of the power of those who plundered them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet they did not listen even to their judges, for they lusted after other gods and bowed down to them. They soon turned aside from the way in which their ancestors had walked, who had obeyed the commandments of the Lord; they did not follow their example.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever the Lord raised up judges for them, the Lord was with the judge, and he delivered them from the hand of their enemies all the days of the judge, for the Lord would be moved to pity by their groaning because of those who persecuted and oppressed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But whenever the judge died, they would relapse and behave worse than their ancestors, following other gods, serving them and bowing down to them. They would not drop any of their practices or their stubborn ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the anger of the Lord was kindled against Israel, and he said, “Because this nation has transgressed my covenant that I commanded their ancestors and have not obeyed my voice,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will no longer drive out before them any of the nations that Joshua left when he died.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In order to test Israel, whether or not they would take care to walk in the way of the Lord as their ancestors did,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Lord had left those nations, not driving them out at once, and had not handed them over to Joshua.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now these are the nations that the Lord left to test all those in Israel who had no experience of war in Canaan
speaker: Narrator

text: (it was only for successive generations of Israelites, to teach war to those who had no experience of it):
speaker: Narrator

text: the five lords of the Philistines, and all the Canaanites, and the Sidonians, and the Hivites who lived on Mount Lebanon, from Mount Baal-hermon as far as Lebo-hamath.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were for the testing of Israel, to know whether Israel would obey the commandments of the Lord that he commanded their ancestors by Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Israelites lived among the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they took their daughters as wives for themselves, and their own daughters they gave to their sons, and they served their gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, forgetting the Lord their God and serving the Baals and the Asherahs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the anger of the Lord was kindled against Israel, and he sold them into the hand of King Cushan-rishathaim of Aram-naharaim, and the Israelites served Cushan-rishathaim eight years.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the Israelites cried out to the Lord, the Lord raised up a deliverer for the Israelites who delivered them, Othniel son of Kenaz, Caleb’s younger brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: The spirit of the Lord came upon him, and he judged Israel; he went out to war, and the Lord gave King Cushan-rishathaim of Aram into his hand, and his hand prevailed over Cushan-rishathaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the land had rest forty years. Then Othniel son of Kenaz died.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites again did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, and the Lord strengthened King Eglon of Moab against Israel, because they had done what was evil in the sight of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: In alliance with the Ammonites and the Amalekites, he went and defeated Israel, and they took possession of the city of palms.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Israelites served King Eglon of Moab eighteen years.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the Israelites cried out to the Lord, the Lord raised up for them a deliverer, Ehud son of Gera, a Benjaminite, a left-handed man. The Israelites sent tribute by him to King Eglon of Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ehud made for himself a sword with two edges, a cubit in length, and he fastened it on his right thigh under his clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he presented the tribute to King Eglon of Moab. Now Eglon was a very fat man.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Ehud had finished presenting the tribute, he sent the people who carried the tribute on their way.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he himself turned back at the sculptured stones near Gilgal and said, “I have a secret message for you, O king.” So the king said, “Silence!” and all his attendants went out from his presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ehud came to him, while he was sitting alone in his cool roof chamber, and said, “I have a message from God for you.” So he rose from his seat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ehud reached with his left hand, took the sword from his right thigh, and thrust it into Eglon’s belly;
speaker: Narrator

text: the hilt also went in after the blade, and the fat closed over the blade, for he did not draw the sword out of his belly, and the dirt came out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ehud went out into the vestibule and closed the doors of the roof chamber on him and locked them.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he had gone, the servants came. When they saw that the doors of the roof chamber were locked, they thought, “He must be relieving himself in the cool chamber.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they waited until they were embarrassed. When he still did not open the doors of the roof chamber, they took the key and opened them. There was their lord lying dead on the floor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ehud escaped while they delayed and passed beyond the sculptured stones and escaped to Seirah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he arrived, he sounded the trumpet in the hill country of Ephraim, and the Israelites went down with him from the hill country, having him at their head.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “Follow after me, for the Lord has given your enemies the Moabites into your hand.” So they went down after him and seized the fords of the Jordan against the Moabites and allowed no one to cross over.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time they killed about ten thousand of the Moabites, all strong, able-bodied men; no one escaped.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moab was subdued that day under the hand of Israel. And the land had rest eighty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him came Shamgar son of Anath, who killed six hundred of the Philistines with an oxgoad. He, too, delivered Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites again did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, after Ehud died.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord sold them into the hand of King Jabin of Canaan, who reigned in Hazor; the commander of his army was Sisera, who lived in Harosheth-ha-goiim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Israelites cried out to the Lord for help, for he had nine hundred chariots of iron and had oppressed the Israelites cruelly twenty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time Deborah, a prophet, wife of Lappidoth, was judging Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: She used to sit under the palm of Deborah between Ramah and Bethel in the hill country of Ephraim, and the Israelites came up to her for judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: She sent and summoned Barak son of Abinoam from Kedesh in Naphtali and said to him, “The Lord, the God of Israel, commands you, ‘Position yourself at Mount Tabor, taking ten thousand from the tribe of Naphtali and the tribe of Zebulun.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will draw out Sisera, the general of Jabin’s army, to meet you by the Wadi Kishon with his chariots and his troops, and I will give him into your hand.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Barak said to her, “If you will go with me, I will go, but if you will not go with me, I will not go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And she said, “I will surely go with you; nevertheless, the road on which you are going will not lead to your glory, for the Lord will sell Sisera into the hand of a woman.” Then Deborah got up and went with Barak to Kedesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Barak summoned Zebulun and Naphtali to Kedesh, and ten thousand warriors went up behind him, and Deborah went up with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Heber the Kenite had separated from the other Kenites, that is, the descendants of Hobab the father-in-law of Moses, and had encamped as far away as Elon-bezaanannim, which is near Kedesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Sisera was told that Barak son of Abinoam had gone up to Mount Tabor,
speaker: Narrator

text: Sisera called out all his chariots, nine hundred chariots of iron, and all the troops who were with him, from Harosheth-ha-goiim to the Wadi Kishon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Deborah said to Barak, “Up! For this is the day on which the Lord has given Sisera into your hand. Has not the Lord gone out before you?” So Barak went down from Mount Tabor with ten thousand warriors following him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord threw Sisera and all his chariots and all his army into a panic before Barak; Sisera got down from his chariot and fled away on foot,
speaker: Narrator

text: while Barak pursued the chariots and the army to Harosheth-ha-goiim. All the army of Sisera fell by the sword; not one was left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Sisera had fled away on foot to the tent of Jael wife of Heber the Kenite, for there was peace between King Jabin of Hazor and the clan of Heber the Kenite.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jael came out to meet Sisera and said to him, “Turn aside, my lord, turn aside to me; have no fear.” So he turned aside to her into the tent, and she covered him with a rug.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to her, “Please give me a little water to drink, for I am thirsty.” So she opened a skin of milk and gave him a drink and covered him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to her, “Stand at the entrance of the tent, and if anybody comes and asks you, ‘Is anyone here?’ say, ‘No.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jael wife of Heber took a tent peg and took a hammer in her hand and went softly to him and drove the peg into his temple, until it went down into the ground—he was lying fast asleep from weariness—and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then, as Barak came in pursuit of Sisera, Jael went out to meet him and said to him, “Come, and I will show you the man whom you are seeking.” So he went into her tent, and there was Sisera lying dead, with the tent peg in his temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: So on that day God subdued King Jabin of Canaan before the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the hand of the Israelites bore harder and harder on King Jabin of Canaan, until they destroyed King Jabin of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Deborah and Barak son of Abinoam sang on that day,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“When locks are long in Israel,
    when the people offer themselves willingly—
    bless the Lord!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Lord, when you went out from Seir,
    when you marched from the region of Edom,
the earth trembled,
    and the heavens poured;
    the clouds indeed poured water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The mountains quaked before the Lord, the One of Sinai,
    before the Lord, the God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the days of Shamgar son of Anath,
    in the days of Jael, caravans ceased,
    and travelers kept to the byways.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The peasantry prospered in Israel;
    they grew fat on plunder,
because you arose, Deborah,
    arose as a mother in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When new gods were chosen,
    then war was in the gates.
Was shield or spear to be seen
    among forty thousand in Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text:
My heart goes out to the commanders of Israel
    who offered themselves willingly among the people.
    Bless the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sing of it, you who ride on white donkeys,
    you who sit on rich carpets,
    and you who walk by the way.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To the sound of musicians at the watering places,
    there they repeat the triumphs of the Lord,
    the triumphs of his peasantry in Israel.
Then down to the gates marched the people of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Awake, awake, Deborah!
    Awake, awake, utter a song!
Arise, Barak, lead away your captives,
    O son of Abinoam.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then down marched the remnant of the nobles;
    the people of the Lord marched down for him against the mighty.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
the chiefs of Issachar came with Deborah,
    and Issachar faithful to Barak;
    into the valley they rushed out at his heels.
Among the clans of Reuben
    there were great searchings of heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why did you tarry among the sheepfolds,
    to hear the piping for the flocks?
Among the clans of Reuben
    there were great searchings of heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gilead stayed beyond the Jordan,
    and Dan, why did he abide with the ships?
Asher sat still at the coast of the sea,
    settling down by his landings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Zebulun is a people that scorned death;
    Naphtali, too, on the heights of the field.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The stars fought from heaven;
    from their courses they fought against Sisera.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The torrent Kishon swept them away,
    the onrushing torrent, the torrent Kishon.
    March on, my soul, with might!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then loud beat the horses’ hoofs
    with the galloping, galloping of his steeds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Curse Meroz, says the angel of the Lord;
    curse bitterly its inhabitants,
because they did not come to the help of the Lord,
    to the help of the Lord against the mighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Most blessed of women be Jael,
    the wife of Heber the Kenite,
    of tent-dwelling women most blessed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Water he asked, milk she gave;
    she brought him curds in a lordly bowl.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Out of the window she peered;
    the mother of Sisera gazed through the lattice:
‘Why is his chariot so long in coming?
    Why tarry the hoofbeats of his chariots?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her wisest ladies make answer;
    indeed, she answers the question herself:
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Are they not finding and dividing the spoil?
    A woman or two for every man;
spoil of dyed stuffs for Sisera,
    spoil of dyed stuffs embroidered,
    two pieces of dyed work embroidered for my neck as spoil?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
So perish all your enemies, O Lord!
    But may your friends be like the sun as it rises in its might.”
And the land had rest forty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, and the Lord gave them into the hand of Midian seven years.
speaker: Narrator

text: The hand of Midian prevailed over Israel, and because of Midian the Israelites provided for themselves hiding places in the mountains, caves and strongholds.
speaker: Narrator

text: For whenever the Israelites put in seed, the Midianites and the Amalekites and the people of the east would come up against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They would encamp against them and destroy the produce of the land, as far as the neighborhood of Gaza, and leave no sustenance in Israel, nor any sheep or ox or donkey.
speaker: Narrator

text: For they and their livestock would come up, and they would even bring their tents, as thick as locusts; neither they nor their camels could be counted, so they wasted the land as they came in.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus Israel was greatly impoverished because of Midian, and the Israelites cried out to the Lord for help.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Israelites cried to the Lord on account of the Midianites,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Lord sent a prophet to the Israelites, and he said to them, “Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: I led you up from Egypt and brought you out of the house of slavery,
speaker: Narrator

text: and I delivered you from the hand of the Egyptians and from the hand of all who oppressed you and drove them out before you and gave you their land,
speaker: Narrator

text: and I said to you, ‘I am the Lord your God; you shall not pay reverence to the gods of the Amorites in whose land you live.’ But you have not given heed to my voice.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the angel of the Lord came and sat under the oak at Ophrah, which belonged to Joash the Abiezrite, as his son Gideon was beating out wheat in the winepress, to hide it from the Midianites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord appeared to him and said to him, “The Lord is with you, you mighty warrior.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon answered him, “But sir, if the Lord is with us, why then has all this happened to us? And where are all his wonderful deeds that our ancestors recounted to us, saying, ‘Did not the Lord bring us up from Egypt?’ But now the Lord has cast us off and given us into the hand of Midian.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord turned to him and said, “Go in this might of yours and deliver Israel from the hand of Midian; I hereby commission you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He responded, “But sir, how can I deliver Israel? My clan is the weakest in Manasseh, and I am the least in my family.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to him, “But I will be with you, and you shall strike down the Midianites, every one of them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to him, “If now I have found favor with you, then show me a sign that it is you who speak with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not depart from here until I come to you and bring out my present and set it before you.” And he said, “I will stay until you return.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Gideon went into his house and prepared a kid and unleavened cakes from an ephah of flour; the meat he put in a basket, and the broth he put in a pot and brought them to him under the oak and presented them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of God said to him, “Take the meat and the unleavened cakes and put them on this rock and pour out the broth.” And he did so.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the angel of the Lord reached out the tip of the staff that was in his hand and touched the meat and the unleavened cakes, and fire sprang up from the rock and consumed the meat and the unleavened cakes, and the angel of the Lord vanished from his sight.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Gideon perceived that it was the angel of the Lord, and Gideon said, “Help me, Lord God! For I have seen the angel of the Lord face to face.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord said to him, “Peace be to you; do not fear; you shall not die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Gideon built an altar there to the Lord and called it, “The Lord is peace.” To this day it still stands at Ophrah, which belongs to the Abiezrites.
speaker: Narrator

text: That night the Lord said to him, “Take your father’s bull, the second bull seven years old, and pull down the altar of Baal that belongs to your father and cut down the sacred pole that is beside it
speaker: Narrator

text: and build an altar to the Lord your God on the top of the stronghold here, in proper order; then take the second bull and offer it as a burnt offering with the wood of the sacred pole that you cut down.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Gideon took ten of his servants and did as the Lord had told him, but because he was too afraid of his family and the townspeople to do it by day, he did it by night.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the townspeople rose early in the morning, the altar of Baal was broken down, and the sacred pole beside it was cut down, and the second bull was offered on the altar that had been built.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they said to one another, “Who has done this?” After searching and inquiring, they were told, “Gideon son of Joash did it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the townspeople said to Joash, “Bring out your son so that he may die, for he has pulled down the altar of Baal and cut down the sacred pole beside it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joash said to all who were arrayed against him, “Will you contend for Baal? Or will you defend his cause? Whoever contends for him shall be put to death by morning. If he is a god, let him contend for himself, because his altar has been pulled down.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore on that day Gideon was called Jerubbaal, that is to say, “Let Baal contend against him,” because he pulled down his altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the Midianites and the Amalekites and the people of the east came together, and they crossed over and encamped in the Valley of Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the spirit of the Lord took possession of Gideon, and he sounded the trumpet, and the Abiezrites were called out to follow him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent messengers throughout all Manasseh, and they, too, were called out to follow him. He also sent messengers to Asher, Zebulun, and Naphtali, and they went up to meet them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Gideon said to God, “In order to see whether you will deliver Israel by my hand, as you have said,
speaker: Narrator

text: I am going to lay a fleece of wool on the threshing floor; if there is dew on the fleece alone, and it is dry on all the ground, then I shall know that you will deliver Israel by my hand, as you have said.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And it was so. When he rose early next morning and squeezed the fleece, he wrung enough dew from the fleece to fill a bowl with water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Gideon said to God, “Do not let your anger burn against me, but let me speak one more time; let me, please, make trial with the fleece just once more; let it be dry only on the fleece, and on all the ground let there be dew.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And God did so that night. It was dry on the fleece only, and on all the ground there was dew.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jerubbaal (that is, Gideon) and all the troops who were with him rose early and encamped beside the spring of Harod, and the camp of Midian was north of them, below the hill of Moreh, in the valley.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Gideon, “The troops with you are too many for me to give the Midianites into their hand. Israel would only take the credit away from me, saying, ‘My own hand has delivered me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, therefore, proclaim this in the hearing of the troops, ‘Whoever is fearful and trembling, let him return home.’ ” Thus Gideon sifted them out; twenty-two thousand returned, and ten thousand remained.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Gideon, “The troops are still too many; take them down to the water, and I will sift them out for you there. When I say, ‘This one shall go with you,’ he shall go with you, and when I say, ‘This one shall not go with you,’ he shall not go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he brought the troops down to the water, and the Lord said to Gideon, “All those who lap the water with their tongues, as a dog laps, you shall put to one side; all those who kneel down to drink, putting their hands to their mouths, you shall put to the other side.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of those who lapped was three hundred, but all the rest of the troops knelt down to drink water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Gideon, “With the three hundred who lapped I will deliver you and give the Midianites into your hand. Let all the others go to their homes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people took provisions in their hands and their trumpets, and he sent all the rest of Israel back to their own tents but retained the three hundred. The camp of Midian was below him in the valley.
speaker: Narrator

text: That same night the Lord said to him, “Get up; attack the camp, for I have given it into your hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you fear to attack, go down to the camp with your servant Purah,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you shall hear what they say, and afterward your hands shall be strengthened to attack the camp.” Then he went down with his servant Purah to the outposts of the armed men who were in the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Midianites and the Amalekites and all the people of the east lay along the valley as thick as locusts, and their camels were without number, countless as the sand on the seashore.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Gideon arrived, there was a man telling a dream to his comrade, and he said, “I had a dream, and in it a cake of barley bread tumbled into the camp of Midian and came to the tent and struck it so that it fell; it turned upside down, and the tent collapsed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And his comrade answered, “This is no other than the sword of Gideon son of Joash, a man of Israel; into his hand God has given Midian and all the army.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Gideon heard the telling of the dream and its interpretation, he worshiped, and he returned to the camp of Israel and said, “Get up, for the Lord has given the army of Midian into your hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After he divided the three hundred men into three companies and put trumpets into the hands of all of them and empty jars, with torches inside the jars,
speaker: Narrator

text: he said to them, “Look at me, and do the same; when I come to the outskirts of the camp, do as I do.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I blow the trumpet, I and all who are with me, then you also blow the trumpets around the whole camp and shout, ‘For the Lord and for Gideon!’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Gideon and the hundred who were with him came to the outskirts of the camp at the beginning of the middle watch, when they had just set the watch, and they blew the trumpets and smashed the jars that were in their hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the three companies blew the trumpets and broke the jars, holding in their left hands the torches and in their right hands the trumpets to blow, and they cried, “A sword for the Lord and for Gideon!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Every man stood in his place all around the camp, and all the men in camp ran; they cried out and fled.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they blew the three hundred trumpets, the Lord set every man’s sword against his fellow and against all the army, and the army fled as far as Beth-shittah toward Zererah, as far as the border of Abel-meholah, by Tabbath.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the men of Israel were called out from Naphtali and from Asher and from all Manasseh, and they pursued after the Midianites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Gideon sent messengers throughout all the hill country of Ephraim, saying, “Come down against the Midianites and seize the waters against them, as far as Beth-barah and the Jordan.” So all the men of Ephraim were called out, and they seized the waters as far as Beth-barah and the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: They captured the two captains of Midian, Oreb and Zeeb; they killed Oreb at the rock of Oreb, and Zeeb they killed at the winepress of Zeeb, as they pursued the Midianites. They brought the heads of Oreb and Zeeb to Gideon beyond the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Ephraimites said to him, “What have you done to us, not to call us when you went to fight against the Midianites?” And they upbraided him violently.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he said to them, “What have I done now in comparison with you? Is not the gleaning of the grapes of Ephraim better than the vintage of Abiezer?
speaker: Narrator

text: God has given into your hands the captains of Midian, Oreb and Zeeb; what have I been able to do in comparison with you?” When he said this, their anger against him subsided.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Gideon came to the Jordan and crossed over, he and the three hundred who were with him, exhausted but still pursuing.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he said to the people of Succoth, “Please give some loaves of bread to my followers, for they are exhausted, and I am pursuing Zebah and Zalmunna, the kings of Midian.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the officials of Succoth said, “Do you already have in your possession the hands of Zebah and Zalmunna, that we should give bread to your army?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon replied, “Well then, when the Lord has given Zebah and Zalmunna into my hand, I will trample your flesh on the thorns of the wilderness and on briers.”
speaker: Narrator

text: From there he went up to Penuel and made the same request of them, and the people of Penuel answered him as the people of Succoth had answered.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he said to the people of Penuel, “When I come back victorious, I will break down this tower.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Zebah and Zalmunna were in Karkor with their army, about fifteen thousand men, all who were left of all the army of the people of the east, for one hundred twenty thousand men bearing arms had fallen.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Gideon went up by the caravan route east of Nobah and Jogbehah and attacked the army, for the army was off its guard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zebah and Zalmunna fled, and he pursued them and took the two kings of Midian, Zebah and Zalmunna, and threw all the army into a panic.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Gideon son of Joash returned from the battle by the ascent of Heres,
speaker: Narrator

text: he caught a young man, one of the people of Succoth, and questioned him, and he listed for him the officials and elders of Succoth, seventy-seven people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he came to the people of Succoth and said, “Here are Zebah and Zalmunna, about whom you taunted me, saying, ‘Do you already have in your possession the hands of Zebah and Zalmunna, that we should give bread to your troops who are exhausted?’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he took the elders of the city, and he took thorns of the wilderness and briers, and with them he trampled the people of Succoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also broke down the tower of Penuel and killed the men of the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to Zebah and Zalmunna, “What about the men whom you killed at Tabor?” They answered, “As you are, so were they, every one of them; they resembled the sons of a king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he replied, “They were my brothers, the sons of my mother; as the Lord lives, if you had saved them alive, I would not kill you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he said to Jether his firstborn, “Go kill them!” But the boy did not draw his sword, for he was afraid, because he was still a boy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Zebah and Zalmunna said, “You come and kill us, for as the man is, so is his strength.” So Gideon went and killed Zebah and Zalmunna, and he took the crescents that were on the necks of their camels.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Israelites said to Gideon, “Rule over us, you and your son and your grandson also, for you have delivered us out of the hand of Midian.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon said to them, “I will not rule over you, and my son will not rule over you; the Lord will rule over you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Gideon said to them, “Let me make a request of you; each of you give me an earring he has taken as spoil.” (For the enemy had golden earrings because they were Ishmaelites.)
speaker: Narrator

text: “We will willingly give them,” they answered. So they spread a garment, and each threw into it an earring he had taken as spoil.
speaker: Narrator

text: The weight of the golden earrings that he requested was one thousand seven hundred shekels of gold (apart from the crescents and the pendants and the purple garments worn by the kings of Midian and the collars that were on the necks of their camels).
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon made an ephod of it and put it in his town, in Ophrah, and all Israel prostituted themselves to it there, and it became a snare to Gideon and to his family.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Midian was subdued before the Israelites, and they lifted up their heads no more. So the land had rest forty years in the days of Gideon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jerubbaal son of Joash went to live in his own house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Gideon had seventy sons, his own offspring, for he had many wives.
speaker: Narrator

text: His concubine who was in Shechem also bore him a son, and he named him Abimelech.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Gideon son of Joash died at a good old age and was buried in the tomb of his father Joash at Ophrah of the Abiezrites.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as Gideon died, the Israelites relapsed and prostituted themselves with the Baals, making Baal-berith their god.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites did not remember the Lord their God, who had rescued them from the hand of all their enemies on every side,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they did not exhibit loyalty to the house of Jerubbaal (that is, Gideon) in return for all the good that he had done to Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Abimelech son of Jerubbaal went to Shechem to his mother’s kinsfolk and said to them and to the whole clan of his mother’s family,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Say in the hearing of all the lords of Shechem, ‘Which is better for you, that all seventy of the sons of Jerubbaal rule over you or that one rule over you?’ Remember also that I am your bone and your flesh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So his mother’s kinsfolk spoke all these words on his behalf in the hearing of all the lords of Shechem, and their hearts inclined to follow Abimelech, for they said, “He is our brother.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They gave him seventy pieces of silver out of the temple of Baal-berith with which Abimelech hired worthless and reckless fellows who followed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went to his father’s house at Ophrah and killed his brothers the sons of Jerubbaal, seventy men, on one stone, but Jotham, the youngest son of Jerubbaal, survived, for he hid himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the lords of Shechem and all Beth-millo came together, and they went and made Abimelech king, by the oak of the pillar at Shechem.
speaker: Narrator

text: When it was told to Jotham, he went and stood on the top of Mount Gerizim and cried aloud and said to them, “Listen to me, you lords of Shechem, so that God may listen to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The trees once went out
    to anoint a king over themselves.
So they said to the olive tree,
    ‘Reign over us.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
The olive tree answered them,
    ‘Shall I stop producing my rich oil
        by which gods and mortals are honored
        and go to sway over the trees?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the trees said to the fig tree,
    ‘You come and reign over us.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the fig tree answered them,
    ‘Shall I stop producing my sweetness
        and my delicious fruit
        and go to sway over the trees?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the trees said to the vine,
    ‘You come and reign over us.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the vine said to them,
    ‘Shall I stop producing my wine
        that cheers gods and mortals
        and go to sway over the trees?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
So all the trees said to the bramble,
    ‘You come and reign over us.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the bramble said to the trees,
    ‘If in good faith you are anointing me king over you,
        then come and take refuge in my shade,
    but if not, let fire come out of the bramble
        and devour the cedars of Lebanon.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now therefore, if you acted in good faith and honor when you made Abimelech king, and if you have dealt well with Jerubbaal and his house and have done to him as his actions deserved—
speaker: Narrator

text: for my father fought for you and risked his life and rescued you from the hand of Midian,
speaker: Narrator

text: but you have risen up against my father’s house this day and have killed his sons, seventy men on one stone, and have made Abimelech, the son of his slave woman, king over the lords of Shechem, because he is your kinsman—
speaker: Narrator

text: if, I say, you have acted in good faith and honor with Jerubbaal and with his house this day, then rejoice in Abimelech, and let him also rejoice in you,
speaker: Narrator

text: but if not, let fire come out from Abimelech and devour the lords of Shechem and Beth-millo, and let fire come out from the lords of Shechem and from Beth-millo and devour Abimelech.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jotham ran away and fled, going to Beer, where he remained for fear of his brother Abimelech.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelech ruled over Israel three years.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God sent an evil spirit between Abimelech and the lords of Shechem, and the lords of Shechem dealt treacherously with Abimelech.
speaker: Narrator

text: This happened so that the violence done to the seventy sons of Jerubbaal might be avenged and their blood be laid on their brother Abimelech, who killed them, and on the lords of Shechem, who strengthened his hands to kill his brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the lords of Shechem set ambushes against him on the mountaintops. They robbed all who passed by them along that way, and it was reported to Abimelech.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Gaal son of Ebed moved into Shechem with his kinsfolk, the lords of Shechem put confidence in him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went out into the field and gathered the grapes from their vineyards, trod them, and celebrated. Then they went into the temple of their god, ate and drank, and ridiculed Abimelech.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gaal son of Ebed said, “Who is Abimelech, and who are we of Shechem, that we should serve him? Did not the son of Jerubbaal and Zebul his officer serve the men of Hamor father of Shechem? Why then should we serve him?
speaker: Narrator

text: If only this people were under my command! Then I would remove Abimelech; I would say to him, ‘Increase your army and come out.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Zebul the ruler of the city heard the words of Gaal son of Ebed, his anger was kindled.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent messengers to Abimelech at Arumah, saying, “Look, Gaal son of Ebed and his kinsfolk have come to Shechem, and they are stirring up the city against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore, go by night, you and the troops who are with you, and lie in wait in the fields.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then early in the morning, as soon as the sun rises, get up and rush on the city, and when he and the troops who are with him come out against you, you may deal with them as best you can.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abimelech and all the troops with him got up by night and lay in wait against Shechem in four companies.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Gaal son of Ebed went out and stood in the entrance of the gate of the city, Abimelech and the troops with him rose from the ambush.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when Gaal saw them, he said to Zebul, “Look, people are coming down from the mountaintops!” And Zebul said to him, “The shadows on the mountains look like people to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Gaal spoke again and said, “Look, people are coming down from Tabbur-erez, and one company is coming from the direction of Elon-meonenim.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Zebul said to him, “Where is your boast now, you who said, ‘Who is Abimelech, that we should serve him?’ Are not these the troops you made light of? Go out now and fight with them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Gaal went out at the head of the lords of Shechem and fought with Abimelech.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelech chased him, and he fled before him. Many fell wounded, up to the entrance of the gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abimelech resided at Arumah, and Zebul drove out Gaal and his kinsfolk, so that they could not live on at Shechem.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the following day the people went out into the fields. When Abimelech was told,
speaker: Narrator

text: he took his troops and divided them into three companies and lay in wait in the fields. When he looked and saw the people coming out of the city, he rose against them and killed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelech and the company that was with him rushed forward and stood at the entrance of the gate of the city, while the two companies rushed on all who were in the fields and killed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelech fought against the city all that day; he took the city and killed the people who were in it, and he razed the city and sowed it with salt.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the lords of the Tower of Shechem heard of it, they entered the stronghold of the temple of El-berith.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelech was told that all the lords of the Tower of Shechem were gathered together.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abimelech went up to Mount Zalmon, he and all the troops who were with him. Abimelech took an ax in his hand, cut down a bundle of brushwood, and took it up and laid it on his shoulder. Then he said to the troops with him, “What you have seen me do, do quickly, as I have done.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So every one of the troops cut down a bundle and following Abimelech put it against the stronghold, and they set the stronghold on fire over them, so that all the people of the Tower of Shechem also died, about a thousand men and women.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abimelech went to Thebez and encamped against Thebez and took it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But there was a strong tower within the city, and all the men and women and all the lords of the city fled to it and shut themselves in, and they went to the roof of the tower.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelech came to the tower and fought against it and came near to the entrance of the tower to burn it with fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: But a certain woman threw an upper millstone on Abimelech’s head and crushed his skull.
speaker: Narrator

text: Immediately he called to the young man who carried his armor and said to him, “Draw your sword and kill me, so people will not say about me, ‘A woman killed him.’ ” So the young man thrust him through, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Israelites saw that Abimelech was dead, they all went home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus God repaid Abimelech for the crime he committed against his father in killing his seventy brothers;
speaker: Narrator

text: and God also made all the wickedness of the people of Shechem fall back on their heads, and on them came the curse of Jotham son of Jerubbaal.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Abimelech, Tola son of Puah son of Dodo, a man of Issachar, who lived at Shamir in the hill country of Ephraim, rose to deliver Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He judged Israel twenty-three years. Then he died and was buried at Shamir.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him came Jair the Gileadite, who judged Israel twenty-two years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had thirty sons who rode on thirty donkeys, and they had thirty towns, which are in the land of Gilead and are called Havvoth-jair to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jair died and was buried in Kamon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites again did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, serving the Baals and the Astartes, the gods of Aram, the gods of Sidon, the gods of Moab, the gods of the Ammonites, and the gods of the Philistines. Thus they abandoned the Lord and did not worship him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the anger of the Lord was kindled against Israel, and he sold them into the hand of the Philistines and into the hand of the Ammonites,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they crushed and oppressed the Israelites that year. For eighteen years they oppressed all the Israelites who were beyond the Jordan in the land of the Amorites, which is in Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Ammonites also crossed the Jordan to fight against Judah and against Benjamin and against the house of Ephraim, so that Israel was greatly distressed.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Israelites cried to the Lord, saying, “We have sinned against you, because we have abandoned our God and have served the Baals.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said to the Israelites, “Did I not deliver you from the Egyptians and from the Amorites, from the Ammonites and from the Philistines?
speaker: Narrator

text: The Sidonians also, and the Amalekites, and the Maonites oppressed you, and you cried to me, and I delivered you out of their hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet you have abandoned me and served other gods; therefore I will deliver you no more.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go and cry to the gods whom you have chosen; let them deliver you in the time of your distress.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Israelites said to the Lord, “We have sinned; do to us whatever seems good to you, but deliver us this day!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they put away the foreign gods from among them and served the Lord, and he could no longer bear to see Israel suffer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Ammonites were called to arms, and they encamped in Gilead, and the Israelites came together, and they encamped at Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The commanders of the people of Gilead said to one another, “Who will begin the fight against the Ammonites? He shall be head over all the inhabitants of Gilead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jephthah the Gileadite, the son of a prostitute, was a mighty warrior. Gilead was the father of Jephthah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gilead’s wife also bore him sons, and when his wife’s sons grew up, they drove Jephthah away, saying to him, “You shall not inherit anything in our father’s house, for you are the son of another woman.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jephthah fled from his brothers and lived in the land of Tob. Outlaws gathered around Jephthah and went raiding with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: After a time the Ammonites made war against Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the Ammonites made war against Israel, the elders of Gilead went to bring Jephthah from the land of Tob.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to Jephthah, “Come and be our commander, so that we may fight with the Ammonites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jephthah said to the elders of Gilead, “Are you not the very ones who rejected me and drove me out of my father’s house? So why do you come to me now when you are in trouble?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The elders of Gilead said to Jephthah, “Nevertheless, we have now turned back to you, so that you may go with us and fight with the Ammonites and become head over us, over all the inhabitants of Gilead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jephthah said to the elders of Gilead, “If you bring me home again to fight with the Ammonites and the Lord gives them over to me, I will be your head.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the elders of Gilead said to Jephthah, “The Lord will be witness between us; we will surely do as you say.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jephthah went with the elders of Gilead, and the people made him head and commander over them, and Jephthah spoke all his words before the Lord at Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jephthah sent messengers to the king of the Ammonites and said, “What is there between you and me, that you have come to me to fight against my land?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of the Ammonites answered the messengers of Jephthah, “Because Israel, on coming from Egypt, took away my land from the Arnon to the Jabbok and to the Jordan; now, therefore, restore it peaceably.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Once again Jephthah sent messengers to the king of the Ammonites
speaker: Narrator

text: and said to him, “Thus says Jephthah: Israel did not take away the land of Moab or the land of the Ammonites,
speaker: Narrator

text: but when they came up from Egypt, Israel went through the wilderness to the Red Sea and came to Kadesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel then sent messengers to the king of Edom, saying, ‘Let us pass through your land,’ but the king of Edom would not listen. They also sent to the king of Moab, but he would not consent. So Israel remained at Kadesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they journeyed through the wilderness, went around the land of Edom and the land of Moab, arrived on the east side of the land of Moab, and camped on the other side of the Arnon. They did not enter the territory of Moab, for the Arnon was the boundary of Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel then sent messengers to King Sihon of the Amorites, king of Heshbon, and Israel said to him, ‘Let us pass through your land to our country.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But Sihon did not trust Israel to pass through his territory, so Sihon gathered all his people together and encamped at Jahaz and fought with Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord, the God of Israel, gave Sihon and all his people into the hand of Israel, and they defeated them, so Israel occupied all the land of the Amorites, who inhabited that country.
speaker: Narrator

text: They occupied all the territory of the Amorites from the Arnon to the Jabbok and from the wilderness to the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now the Lord, the God of Israel, has conquered the Amorites for the benefit of his people Israel. Do you intend to take their place?
speaker: Narrator

text: Should you not possess what your god Chemosh gives you to possess? And should we not be the ones to possess everything that the Lord our God has conquered for our benefit?
speaker: Narrator

text: Now are you any better than King Balak son of Zippor of Moab? Did he ever enter into conflict with Israel, or did he ever go to war with them?
speaker: Narrator

text: While Israel lived in Heshbon and its villages, and in Aroer and its villages, and in all the towns that are along the Arnon, three hundred years, why did you not recover them within that time?
speaker: Narrator

text: It is not I who have sinned against you, but you are the one who does me wrong by making war on me. Let the Lord, who is judge, decide today for the Israelites or for the Ammonites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the king of the Ammonites did not heed the message that Jephthah sent him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the spirit of the Lord came upon Jephthah, and he passed through Gilead and Manasseh. He passed on to Mizpah of Gilead, and from Mizpah of Gilead he passed on to the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jephthah made a vow to the Lord and said, “If you will give the Ammonites into my hand,
speaker: Narrator

text: then whatever comes out of the doors of my house to meet me, when I return victorious from the Ammonites, shall be the Lord’s, to be offered up by me as a burnt offering.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jephthah crossed over to the Ammonites to fight against them, and the Lord gave them into his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: He inflicted a massive defeat on them from Aroer to the neighborhood of Minnith, twenty towns, and as far as Abel-keramim. So the Ammonites were subdued before the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jephthah came to his home at Mizpah, and there was his daughter coming out to meet him with timbrels and with dancing. She was his only child; he had no son or daughter except her.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he saw her, he tore his clothes and said, “Alas, my daughter! You have brought me very low; you have become the cause of great trouble to me. For I have opened my mouth to the Lord, and I cannot take back my vow.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She said to him, “My father, if you have opened your mouth to the Lord, do to me according to what has gone out of your mouth, now that the Lord has given you vengeance against your enemies, the Ammonites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And she said to her father, “Let this thing be done for me: grant me two months, so that I may go and wander on the mountains and bewail my virginity, my companions and I.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go,” he said, and he sent her away for two months. So she departed, she and her companions, and bewailed her virginity on the mountains.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the end of two months, she returned to her father, who did with her according to the vow he had made. She had never slept with a man. So there arose an Israelite custom that
speaker: Narrator

text: for four days every year the daughters of Israel would go out to lament the daughter of Jephthah the Gileadite.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Ephraim were called to arms, and they crossed to Zaphon and said to Jephthah, “Why did you cross over to fight against the Ammonites and did not call us to go with you? We will burn your house down over you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jephthah said to them, “My people and I were engaged in conflict with the Ammonites who oppressed us severely. But when I called you, you did not deliver me from their hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I saw that you would not deliver me, I took my life in my hand and crossed over against the Ammonites, and the Lord gave them into my hand. Why then have you come up to me this day, to fight against me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jephthah gathered all the men of Gilead and fought with Ephraim, and the men of Gilead defeated Ephraim, because they said, “You are fugitives from Ephraim, you Gileadites, in the heart of Ephraim and Manasseh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Gileadites took the fords of the Jordan against the Ephraimites. Whenever one of the fugitives of Ephraim said, “Let me go over,” the men of Gilead would say to him, “Are you an Ephraimite?” When he said, “No,”
speaker: Narrator

text: they said to him, “Then say Shibboleth,” and he said, “Sibboleth,” for he could not pronounce it right. Then they seized him and killed him at the fords of the Jordan. Forty-two thousand of the Ephraimites fell at that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jephthah judged Israel six years. Then Jephthah the Gileadite died and was buried in his town in Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him Ibzan of Bethlehem judged Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had thirty sons. He gave his thirty daughters in marriage outside his clan and brought in thirty young women from outside for his sons. He judged Israel seven years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ibzan died and was buried at Bethlehem.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him Elon the Zebulunite judged Israel, and he judged Israel ten years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elon the Zebulunite died and was buried at Aijalon in the land of Zebulun.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him Abdon son of Hillel the Pirathonite judged Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had forty sons and thirty grandsons who rode on seventy donkeys; he judged Israel eight years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abdon son of Hillel the Pirathonite died and was buried at Pirathon in the land of Ephraim, in the hill country of the Amalekites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites again did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, and the Lord gave them into the hand of the Philistines forty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a certain man of Zorah, of the tribe of the Danites, whose name was Manoah. His wife was barren, having borne no children.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the angel of the Lord appeared to the woman and said to her, “Although you are barren, having borne no children, you shall conceive and bear a son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now be careful not to drink wine or strong drink or to eat anything unclean,
speaker: Narrator

text: for you shall conceive and bear a son. No razor is to come on his head, for the boy shall be a nazirite to God from birth. It is he who shall begin to deliver Israel from the hand of the Philistines.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the woman came and told her husband, “A man of God came to me, and his appearance was like that of an angel of God, most awe-inspiring; I did not ask him where he came from, and he did not tell me his name,
speaker: Narrator

text: but he said to me, ‘You shall conceive and bear a son. So then, drink no wine or strong drink and eat nothing unclean, for the boy shall be a nazirite to God from birth to the day of his death.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Manoah entreated the Lord and said, “O my Lord, I pray, let the man of God whom you sent come to us again and teach us what we are to do concerning the boy who will be born.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God listened to Manoah, and the angel of God came again to the woman as she sat in the field, but her husband Manoah was not with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the woman ran quickly and told her husband, “The man who came to me the other day has appeared to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Manoah got up and followed his wife and came to the man and said to him, “Are you the man who spoke to this woman?” And he said, “I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Manoah said, “Now when your words come true, what is to be the boy’s rule of life; what is he to do?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord said to Manoah, “Let the woman give heed to all that I said to her.
speaker: Narrator

text: She may not eat of anything that comes from the vine. She is not to drink wine or strong drink or eat any unclean thing. She is to observe everything that I commanded her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Manoah said to the angel of the Lord, “Allow us to detain you and prepare a kid for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord said to Manoah, “If you detain me, I will not eat your food, but if you want to prepare a burnt offering, then offer it to the Lord.” (For Manoah did not know that he was the angel of the Lord.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Manoah said to the angel of the Lord, “What is your name, so that we may honor you when your words come true?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the angel of the Lord said to him, “Why do you ask my name? It is too wonderful.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Manoah took the kid with the grain offering and offered it on the rock to the Lord, to him who works wonders.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the flame went up toward heaven from the altar, the angel of the Lord ascended in the flame of the altar while Manoah and his wife looked on, and they fell on their faces to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord did not appear again to Manoah and his wife. Then Manoah realized that it was the angel of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Manoah said to his wife, “We shall surely die, for we have seen God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But his wife said to him, “If the Lord had meant to kill us, he would not have accepted a burnt offering and a grain offering at our hands or shown us all these things or announced to us such things as these.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman bore a son and named him Samson. The boy grew, and the Lord blessed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The spirit of the Lord began to stir him in Mahaneh-dan, between Zorah and Eshtaol.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once Samson went down to Timnah, and at Timnah he saw a Philistine woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he came up and told his father and mother, “I saw a Philistine woman at Timnah; now get her for me as my wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But his father and mother said to him, “Is there not a woman among your kin or among all our people, that you must go to take a wife from the uncircumcised Philistines?” But Samson said to his father, “Get her for me, because she pleases me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: His father and mother did not know that this was from the Lord, for he was seeking a pretext to act against the Philistines. At that time the Philistines had dominion over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samson went down with his father and mother to Timnah. When he came to the vineyards of Timnah, suddenly a young lion roared at him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The spirit of the Lord rushed on him, and he tore the lion apart barehanded as one might tear apart a kid. But he did not tell his father or his mother what he had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he went down and talked with the woman, and she pleased Samson.
speaker: Narrator

text: After a while he returned to marry her, and he turned aside to see the carcass of the lion, and there was a swarm of bees in the body of the lion and honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: He scraped it out into his hands and went on, eating as he went. When he came to his father and mother, he gave some to them, and they ate it. But he did not tell them that he had taken the honey from the carcass of the lion.
speaker: Narrator

text: His father went down to the woman, and Samson made a feast there, as the young men were accustomed to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the people saw him, they brought thirty companions to be with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson said to them, “Let me now put a riddle to you. If you can explain it to me within the seven days of the feast and find it out, then I will give you thirty linen garments and thirty festal garments.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you cannot explain it to me, then you shall give me thirty linen garments and thirty festal garments.” So they said to him, “Ask your riddle; let us hear it.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said to them,
“Out of the eater came something to eat.
Out of the strong came something sweet.”
But for three days they could not explain the riddle.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the fourth day they said to Samson’s wife, “Coax your husband to explain the riddle to us, or we will burn you and your father’s house with fire. Have you invited us here to impoverish us?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Samson’s wife wept before him, saying, “You hate me; you do not really love me. You have asked a riddle of my people, but you have not explained it to me.” He said to her, “Look, I have not told my father or my mother. Why should I tell you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: She wept before him the seven days that their feast lasted, and because she nagged him, on the seventh day he told her. Then she explained the riddle to her people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The men of the town said to him on the seventh day before the sun went down,
“What is sweeter than honey?
What is stronger than a lion?”
And he said to them,
“If you had not plowed with my heifer,
you would not have found out my riddle.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the spirit of the Lord rushed on him, and he went down to Ashkelon. He killed thirty men of the town, took their spoil, and gave the festal garments to those who had explained the riddle. In hot anger he went back to his father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Samson’s wife was given to his companion, who had been his best man.
speaker: Narrator

text: After a while, at the time of the wheat harvest, Samson went to visit his wife, bringing along a kid. He said, “I want to go into my wife’s room.” But her father would not allow him to go in.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her father said, “I was sure that you had rejected her, so I gave her to your companion. Is not her younger sister prettier than she? Why not take her instead?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson said to them, “This time, when I do mischief to the Philistines, I will be without blame.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Samson went and caught three hundred foxes and took some torches, and he turned the foxes tail to tail and put a torch between each pair of tails.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he had set fire to the torches, he let the foxes go into the standing grain of the Philistines and burned up the shocks and the standing grain, as well as the vineyards and olive groves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Philistines asked, “Who has done this?” And they said, “Samson, the son-in-law of the Timnite, because he has taken Samson’s wife and given her to his companion.” So the Philistines came up and burned her and her father.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson said to them, “If this is what you do, I swear I will not stop until I have taken revenge on you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He struck them down hip and thigh with a massive defeat, and he went down and stayed in the cleft of the rock of Etam.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Philistines came up and encamped in Judah and made a raid on Lehi.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Judah said, “Why have you come up against us?” They said, “We have come up to bind Samson, to do to him as he did to us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then three thousand men of Judah went down to the cleft of the rock of Etam, and they said to Samson, “Do you not know that the Philistines are rulers over us? What then have you done to us?” He replied, “As they did to me, so I have done to them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to him, “We have come down to bind you, so that we may give you into the hands of the Philistines.” Samson answered them, “Swear to me that you yourselves will not attack me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to him, “No, we will only bind you and give you into their hands; we will not kill you.” So they bound him with two new ropes and brought him up from the rock.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he came to Lehi, the Philistines came shouting to meet him, and the spirit of the Lord rushed on him, and the ropes that were on his arms became like flax that has caught fire, and his bonds melted off his hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he found a fresh jawbone of a donkey, reached down and took it, and with it he killed a thousand men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And Samson said,
“With the jawbone of a donkey,
    heaps upon heaps,
with the jawbone of a donkey
    I have slain a thousand men.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he had finished speaking, he threw away the jawbone, and that place was called Ramath-lehi.
speaker: Narrator

text: By then he was very thirsty, and he called on the Lord, saying, “You have granted this great victory by the hand of your servant. Am I now to die of thirst and fall into the hands of the uncircumcised?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So God split open the hollow place that is at Lehi, and water came from it. When he drank, his spirit returned, and he revived. Therefore it was named En-hakkore, which is at Lehi to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he judged Israel in the days of the Philistines twenty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once Samson went to Gaza, where he saw a prostitute and went in to her.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Gazites were told, “Samson has come here.” So they circled around and lay in wait for him all night at the city gate. They kept quiet all night, thinking, “Let us wait until the light of the morning; then we will kill him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Samson lay only until midnight. Then at midnight he rose up, took hold of the doors of the city gate and the two posts, pulled them up, bar and all, put them on his shoulders, and carried them to the top of the hill that is in front of Hebron.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this he fell in love with a woman in the valley of Sorek whose name was Delilah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lords of the Philistines came to her and said to her, “Coax him, and find out what makes his strength so great and how we may overpower him, so that we may bind him in order to subdue him, and we will each give you eleven hundred pieces of silver.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Delilah said to Samson, “Please tell me what makes your strength so great and how you could be bound, so that one could subdue you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson said to her, “If they bind me with seven fresh bowstrings that are not dried out, then I shall become weak and be like anyone else.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the lords of the Philistines brought her seven fresh bowstrings that had not dried out, and she bound him with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: While men were lying in wait in an inner chamber, she said to him, “The Philistines are upon you, Samson!” But he snapped the bowstrings as a strand of fiber snaps when it touches the fire. So the secret of his strength was not known.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Delilah said to Samson, “You have mocked me and told me lies; please tell me how you could be bound.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to her, “If they bind me with new ropes that have not been used, then I shall become weak and be like anyone else.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Delilah took new ropes and bound him with them and said to him, “The Philistines are upon you, Samson!” (The men lying in wait were in an inner chamber.) But he snapped the ropes off his arms like a thread.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Delilah said to Samson, “Until now you have mocked me and told me lies; tell me how you could be bound.” He said to her, “If you weave the seven locks of my head with the web and make it tight with the pin, then I shall become weak and be like anyone else.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So while he slept, Delilah took the seven locks of his head and wove them into the web and made them tight with the pin. Then she said to him, “The Philistines are upon you, Samson!” But he awoke from his sleep and pulled away the pin, the loom, and the web.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she said to him, “How can you say, ‘I love you,’ when your heart is not with me? You have mocked me three times now and have not told me what makes your strength so great.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally, after she had nagged him with her words day after day and pestered him, he was tired to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he told her his whole secret and said to her, “A razor has never come upon my head, for I have been a nazirite to God from my mother’s womb. If my head were shaved, then my strength would leave me; I would become weak and be like anyone else.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Delilah realized that he had told her his whole secret, she sent and called the lords of the Philistines, saying, “This time come up, for he has told his whole secret to me.” Then the lords of the Philistines came up to her and brought the money in their hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: She let him fall asleep on her lap, and she called a man and had him shave off the seven locks of his head. He began to weaken, and his strength left him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she said, “The Philistines are upon you, Samson!” When he awoke from his sleep, he thought, “I will go out as at other times and shake myself free.” But he did not know that the Lord had left him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Philistines seized him and gouged out his eyes. They brought him down to Gaza and bound him with bronze shackles, and he ground at the mill in the prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the hair of his head began to grow again after it had been shaved.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the lords of the Philistines gathered to offer a great sacrifice to their god Dagon and to rejoice, for they said, “Our god has given Samson our enemy into our hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the people saw him, they praised their god, for they said, “Our god has given our enemy into our hand, the ravager of our country, who has killed many of us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And when their hearts were merry, they said, “Call Samson, and let him entertain us.” So they called Samson out of the prison, and he performed for them. They made him stand between the pillars,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Samson said to the attendant who held him by the hand, “Let me feel the pillars on which the house rests, so that I may lean against them.”
speaker: Narrator
